2.00.text:
It's not nice, asking the public 
 for money.

3.96.text:
Young people of Manchester 
 have had enough.

5.88.text: We're not getting any fucking help.

7.60.text:
I'm a land pirate 
 and I stole your building.

9.44.text:
If you want it back, take me 
 to court and get it back.

11.84.text:
Cover your face! 
 No-one's happy around here.

28.56.text:
You look out of your window 
 right now in Wythenshawe,

31.92.text:
you see a nine-year-old kid throw 
 a brick through your car window,

36.80.text: what do you do about it?

38.92.text:
Phone the police? 
 Police won't come out.

40.92.text:
Would you go out and try 
 and grab hold of him?

44.36.text:
If you touch him, 
 that's assault on a minor,

46.48.text:
the police will definitely 
 come out for that.

48.52.text: Would you go and see his parents?

50.28.text:
There might be drug 
 or alcohol problems.

52.28.text:
If you go outside again 
 there might be a gang of them.

55.44.text:
They might come back the night after
 do your car in, do your house in.

59.72.text:
What would you do? Nothing. 
 You do nothing about it.

63.44.text:
What makes that 
 social scenario worse,

67.60.text:
worse than the fact 
 that you would do nothing about it?

72.44.text:
The fact that the kid knows there's 
 nothing you can do about it.

89.32.text:
Greg lives on Wythenshawe's 
 Benchill Estate,

92.12.text:
a place made famous when 
 David Cameron was accosted

95.28.text: by a lad waving gun signs.

97.68.text:
Wythenshawe is a very large 
 geographical place.

101.12.text:
Very defined gangs, you know, 
 you'll see the tags.

103.76.text:
If we could unite the estates, 
 if we could do that, why don't we?

110.12.text: So what do you call it?

114.40.text:
Greg used to run the doors 
 around Manchester,

119.52.text:
but for nearly 20 years 
 he's run his own gym

122.36.text:
helping get local kids 
 off the street.

124.84.text:
Why a gym? Because gyms speak 
 a common language, don't they?

127.60.text:
You've got swathes of kids that 
 won't be seen dead in a youth club

130.96.text: and the cool kids stay away,

132.28.text:
so if they stay away, 
 it's not a cool place.

137.36.text: I remember coming with my dad,

139.12.text:
and just bit by bit I used to start 
 training myself as I got older.

143.16.text:
Greg's gym has helped take local 
 lad Jimmy from scrawny youth

150.12.text:
Trained there for like a lot 
 of me big fights.

154.40.text:
cos in winter it's bitter 
 in here, you get what I mean?

158.12.text:
You grab an old cold bar, it puts 
 hairs on your chest, doesn't it?

163.60.text: Do you want to jump in with me or..?

165.56.text:
I'll jump in with you, if that's 
 all right. Jump in with me.

168.16.text: Jump in with me for the day.

169.60.text:
Right, I'm off mate. Right I'll 
 see you in a bit. See in a bit.

174.08.text:
After starting 
 training at Greg's gym,

177.56.text:
Jimmy quickly rose through 
 the amateur boxing ranks

181.32.text:
before turning pro and getting 
 a shot at the world title,

191.88.text:
'And then the white towel 
 is coming in.

194.08.text:
'They know that should've 
 been a knock down.

196.36.text:
'He holds the white towel out 
 and the fight is all over.

203.24.text:
In the 14 months since his defeat, 
 Jimmy's had surgery on an elbow,

207.84.text:
and fought a handful of low-key 
 fights

210.52.text:
as he tries to rebuild his 
 career.

212.92.text:
With the money from his world title 
 fight, he's bought a house,

217.48.text: got married and had a kid.

220.12.text:
Don't know your boys name yet. 
 Oh, Jimmy. Jimmy Junior.

222.60.text:
Jimmy, of course. Real men 
 call their kids after themselves.

225.76.text:
I'm Jimmy, my son's Jimmy, 
 my dad's Jimmy,

229.32.text:
my son's son will be Jimmy because 
 I'll get him in a headlock if not.

232.72.text:
My grandad's Pascal, 
 but his brother is called Jimmy

237.16.text:
and my grandad's grandad 
 is Jimmy.

240.08.text: So yeah, there's a fair few of us.

242.88.text:
Let me find this little monster 
 and I'll bring him down.

246.16.text:
Jan? Yeah? Are you changed? 
 Hang on, just changing him.

251.44.text:
Do you want to see the biggest head 
 on a baby you'll ever see?

254.00.text:
This is pure Irish 
 and good breast milk for you.

263.56.text:
Tonight, Jimmy's fighting 
 to get back on the bill

274.76.text:
You're due a sleep, though, aren't 
 you? You're getting a bit naughty.

279.84.text:
They were too small for him 
 when he was first born

282.56.text: so he can wear them now, can't he?

284.12.text:
Yeah, pop them on 
 over his little babygrow. Yeah.

289.96.text:
It's a chance to get his career back
 on track and secure a major payday.

295.32.text:
All right, babes. See you later. 
 OK! See you later.

298.20.text: For him and his young family.

310.00.text:
Have you got folks at home? 
 Do you live with your parents?

314.68.text:
What do they say about 
 what you're up to?

334.00.text:
We've only inherited it from them. 
 What do you mean?

350.16.text:
How you doing? All right, man. 
 Mind if I join you? No, no.

362.92.text: Excuse me, sir, do you have 39p?

366.20.text: Yo, bro! Don't do that here, mate.

369.84.text:
I'll give it to you, come 
 here, and I'll give it to you.

373.56.text: Just take it in copper, bro.

380.24.text:
Seen him around? Yeah, I've seen 
 him around and that, yeah.

384.08.text:
Just seems a bit weird that 
 you're having to give him 39p.

388.20.text:
Just to fuck him off cos 
 otherwise he's going to fuck me up.

392.80.text:
He's asking people, I could be 
 getting that, know what I mean?

396.36.text:
With such slim pickings, Jordan 
 can't afford a hostel for the night.

402.64.text:
I'm staying in the squat, 
 the Corner House.

406.56.text:
The owners of the 
 Cornerhouse Cinema

408.84.text: have won a High Court ruling

410.60.text:
allowing them to evict 
 everyone in the building.

413.84.text:
In a couple of days, the squatters 
 will be forced out,

417.36.text:
whether they have 
 somewhere to go or not.

420.28.text:
I'll glue myself to the windows, 
 I'll chain myself to the door,

423.12.text:
I'll put a D-lock round my neck 
 and round the inspector's neck,

426.32.text:
and then put a chain around the 
 bloody padlock on the building

429.04.text:
and say, "Right, lock on, you're 
 not throwing any of us out today.".

439.00.text:
In an effort to reduce 
 the nation's welfare bill,

441.92.text:
benefits across the country 
 have been cut.

444.92.text:
Mikey thinks it's disproportionately
 affecting the poor

448.44.text:
so he's running a voluntary 
 drop-in for locals

451.36.text:
who are struggling 
 to make ends meet.

453.76.text:
A lot of people are being kicked off
 the benefits unfairly,

457.48.text:
so they are looking 
 for a reason to sanction you,

460.04.text:
they're looking for a reason to take
 the only money that you have

463.16.text:
to pay for your accommodation, 
 to pay for your food, your water,

466.68.text:
gas and electricity, 
 and to pay for your life.

468.84.text:
And they're looking for an excuse 
 to kick you off it.

477.64.text:
People just give up and end up on 
 the street, end up doing drugs,

481.16.text: end up with mental health problems.

483.24.text:
You can't really come back 
 from something like that.

488.40.text:
What type of things have 
 led you to be in this situation?

498.12.text:
I was living with my mum 
 and it was hard, you know,

501.28.text:
to keep up with rent payments 
 and stuff like that,

504.00.text:
and she was drinking a lot so she 
 went into a dry house, you know,

507.04.text: to try and get off the drink.

509.08.text:
So I went to the hostel 
 cos she was moving house.

514.84.text:
There was issues 
 in your hostel then?

517.12.text:
Yeah. You'd been there for six, 
 seven months?

522.44.text:
And not moving you on at all? 
 Not really.

525.84.text: So, tell me a bit about the hostel.

527.92.text:
It's not nice. 
 Got to keep your door locked.

530.00.text:
If you go to the toilet, or 
 whatever, you lock your door

532.40.text:
cos you don't want to risk 
 someone taking a load of stuff.

535.60.text:
Someone had their trackies nicked 
 the other day, just off a radiator.

539.68.text:
Like an estimated 83,000 young 
 people, Jack has nowhere to live.

545.52.text: Yes, he's been put up in a hostel,

548.12.text:
but housing benefit only covers 
 his full rent if he's not working.

552.88.text: I'm just on benefits at the moment.

554.52.text:
I can't work cause my rent's £255.69
 a week with a £10.30 service charge.

561.32.text:
So your rent's 250 a week, 
 £1,000 a month?

563.76.text:
Over, just over, yeah. Plus 
 a £10.30 service charge on top.

567.44.text:
So a normal job pays 
 on average about £250 a week,

571.84.text:
and my rent's £255 a week, 
 so even if I'm like working

575.04.text:
for a full week, I've still not 
 got enough money to cover the rent.

581.56.text: With the price it is in a hostel,

583.24.text:
you've not even got enough money 
 to save up to get out

586.48.text:
to even go private, so you're forced
 into waiting for a council gaff.

593.52.text:
So everyone tries to find their own 
 way

595.96.text:
of making a bit of money 
 on the side.

598.04.text: What do you do? I do tattoos, me.

602.40.text:
Just to make a bit 
 of extra change really,

605.44.text:
cos you can't 
 really live off £10 a day,

607.80.text:
or I can't anyway, 
 it's too difficult.

614.48.text: Got £55 and a bottle of JD.

617.48.text: What will you do with the money?

618.96.text:
I'll probably just get a haircut 
 and a top up for my phone.

632.56.text:
'The police have completely 
 cordoned off Whitworth Street West.

635.44.text:
'That means you can't get 
 onto Oxford Road...'

640.16.text:
After a High Court ruling, 
 police and bailiffs are moving in

643.96.text:
to evict the homeless 
 and the protesters

647.72.text:
You can send me to jail 
 all you want, you know?

649.92.text:
Jail's like... It's more 
 comfortable than this.

652.64.text:
Has the Council come up with a plan 
 for how to house

656.12.text:
the dozens of homeless people 
 who are living in this building?

659.20.text:
The Council have no plan, 
 other than passing the buck

661.64.text:
and then throwing you 
 to a private landlord.

670.92.text:
Do you think you could cope 
 with living on the street?

673.08.text: Not really. No, it'd do me in.

688.92.text:
I know a lot of homeless people 
 who'd rather be in prison.

691.68.text:
When you're in prison, 
 you've got a roof over your head,

696.08.text:
You don't have people coming out 
 of a pub in the middle of the night

698.84.text: pissing on you, and shit like that.

700.40.text:
The streets is just 
 the roughest place to be.

702.52.text:
When the bailiffs kick the door 
 down, when everyone gets kicked out,

705.52.text:
where do those dozens of people go? 
 Nowhere!

709.20.text:
If you live in a city centre, 
 just be honest with yourself

712.68.text:
and look around and feel the guilt 
 when you look at these people

717.56.text:
because essentially it's our fault, 
 you know?

720.92.text:
It is, it's our fault 
 because we allow it to happen.

738.08.text:
There's a man who fights 
 for people's rights.

740.64.text:
There's a man who fights for people 
 who can't fight for themselves.

744.08.text:
For now, the Cornerhouse squatters 
 have resisted the eviction.

752.96.text: But the bailiffs will be back.

763.64.text:
They all look down when they see me.
 They're all pussies.
